questions.question: Diseases that follow seasonal trend are?

options.A: Varicella
options.C: Rubella
options.D: All of the above

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Rubella shows cyclical trends. Cyclical trends Seasonal trends They occur in cycles spread over short periods of time. Cycles are associated with seasons. Examples: Measles: every 2-3 years. Rubella: every 6-9 years. Influenza: every 7-10 years. Examples: Measles. Varicella. Cerebro-spinal meningitis. Upper respiratory tract infections. Malaria. Sunstroke. Hay fever. Snakebite. Rubella Note: Road traffic accidents can be cyclical (more during weekends) and seasonal (more common in winter). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 73

questions.question: What is an ecological fallacy or an ecological bias?

options.A: Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level.
options.B: Associations observed at an individual level may not hold true at the group level.
options.C: Associations observed at a group level will apply to individual levels.
options.D: Associations at the group level and individual levels are opposite to each other.

questions.explanation: level. Correct Answer: A) Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level. Explanation: Ecological bias is found in ecological study designs, where the associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level. Reference: IAPSM's Textbook of Community Medicine, 2nd Edition, Page 157

questions.question: Among the following statements, which is true regarding ecological study designs?

options.A: It is expensive
options.C: Associations observed at the group level always hold true at the individual level
options.D: Complex study model

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Analysis at a population level Explanation: Ecological studies analyse associations between variables at the group or population level. Ecological studies: Aspect Description Definition It analyses associations between variables at the group or population level by using secondary data. Strengths Simple and cost-effective. It can suggest potential cause-effect relationships. Useful for studying large populations and trends over time. Limitations Ecological Fallacy: Associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level. Examples Study correlating average dietary fat consumption with breast cancer incidence across 20 developed countries. Note: Ecological bias is found in ecological study designs, where the associations observed at the group level may not hold true at the individual level. Reference: IAPSM’s Textbook of Community Medicine, 2nd Edition, Page 157

questions.question: Which of the following studies takes repeated observations from a population via follow-ups?

options.A: Cross-sectional
options.C: Both
options.D: None

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Longitudinal Explanation: In longitudinal studies, observations are repeated, while in cross-sectional studies, observations are done only once. Longitudinal studies Cross-sectional studies Observations are repeated using follow-ups in a population. Observations are done only once in the population. They are carried over a long period of time (minimum one year). They are carried over a given point/period of time. It helps to discover the occurrence of new cases (Incidence rate). It helps to discover the existence of both old and new cases (Prevalence rate). It helps to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors. They do not help to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors. It is time-consuming, difficult, and costly. It is not time-consuming, not difficult, and cheap. Reference: Community Medicine with Recent Advances, AH Suryakantha, 3rd Edition, Page 253

questions.question: All of the following statements regarding cross-sectional study are true except?

options.A: Observations are done only once
options.B: This is cheap and not time-consuming
options.C: Does help to study the natural history of disease
options.D: Carried over a given point of time or period of time

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Does help to study the natural history of disease Explanation: Cross-sectional studies do not help in studying the natural history of disease. Cross-sectional studies: It is also known as prevalence study. Observations are done only once in the population (Option A) . Carried over a given point of time or period of time (Option D) . This helps to find out the existence of both old and new cases (Prevalence rate). This does not help to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors. This is not time-consuming, not difficult, and cheap (Option B) . Reference: Community Medicine with Recent Advances, AH Suryakantha, 3rd Edition, Page 253

questions.question: In a population of 1000 individuals, 200 develop oral cancers over a 10-year period. Among the total population, 100 are regular tobacco users, from which 60 developed oral cancers. Calculate the Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 22% Explanation: Tobacco user No Tobacco Total Disease Present 60 140 200 Disease Absent 40 760 800 Total 100 900 1000 Calculate the overall incidence rate (I total ) of oral cancers in the population: Given: Total population (N) = 1000 Cases of oral cancers (C) = 200 Total = 200/1000 = 0.2 The overall incidence rate of oral cancers in the population (I total ) is 0.2, or 20%. Calculate the incidence rate (I unexposed ) of oral cancers in non-tobacco users: Given: Non-tobacco users = Total population (N) - Tobacco users. Cases of oral cancers among non-tobacco users = Total cases - Cases among tobacco users. Therefore, the incidence rate of oral cancers among non-tobacco users (I unexposed ) is 0.1556 or 15.56%. Population Attributable Risk (PAR): PAR = (0.20. − 0.1556 I )/0.2 = 0.044/ 0.2 = 0.22 Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population is approximately 0.22 or 22% Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 86, 87

questions.question: In a study of 500 children, 200 were vaccinated against measles, and 300 were not. Out of the 200 vaccinated children, 10 developed measles. Among the 300 unvaccinated children, 90 developed measles. Calculate the attributable risk of developing measles due to lack of vaccination.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 0.83 Explanation: Vaccinated Not Vaccinated Total Disease Present 10 90 100 Disease Absent 190 210 400 Total 200 300 500 To calculate the attributable risk (AR), we use the formula: AR = (Incidence in Exposed) − (Incidence in Unexposed) Incidence in Exposed (unvaccinated): Incidence in Unexposed (vaccinated): Attributable Risk: Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 86, 87

questions.question: A study was conducted over 10 years to evaluate the risk of mesothelioma among people working in the ship-based industry. The study included 200 workers exposed to asbestos and 300 workers not exposed to asbestos. Among those exposed, 40 developed mesothelioma and died at the terminal stage, while only 5 of the unexposed group developed mesothelioma and died. What is the relative risk of developing mesothelioma and dying for workers exposed to asbestos compared to those not exposed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 12.00 Explanation: Exposed to Asbestos Not Exposed to Asbestos Total Mesothelioma (Disease Present) 40 5 45 No Mesothelioma (Disease Absent) 160 295 455 Total 200 300 500 Calculate the incidence rate of mesothelioma in both exposed and unexposed groups. Incidence in the exposed group: Incidence in the unexposed group: Relative risk (RR): This is approximately 12.00.

questions.question: A community health department has noted rising cirrhosis cases. To investigate if alcohol consumption is a risk factor, what study design should health workers use?

options.A: Cross-Sectional Study
options.C: Cohort Study
options.D: Randomised Controlled Trial

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cohort Study Explanation: A cohort study follows a group of individuals over time to see who develops cirrhosis and compares the incidence between those who consume alcohol and those who do not. This design can establish a temporal relationship and directly measure the risk of developing cirrhosis, making it the most appropriate choice for this investigation. Cohort studies are a type of observational study design that follows a group of people (a cohort) over time to assess the outcomes of exposure to certain risk factors or interventions. Indications to conduct a cohort study: Exposure Assessment Incidence Calculation Time Relationship Rare Exposures Multiple Outcomes Long Latency Period Natural Course Randomised controlled trial (RCT) involves randomly assigning participants to different interventions to compare outcomes. While RCTs are the gold standard for establishing causality, it would be unethical and impractical to randomly assign individuals to consume alcohol to study its effects on cirrhosis development. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 83

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the cross-product ratio?

options.A: It is also known as the incidence rate.
options.B: It measures the relative risk in cohort studies.
options.C: It provides an estimation of disease risk associated with exposure.
options.D: A value of > 1 indicates an inverse association or protective factor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It provides an estimation of disease risk associated with exposure. Explanation: Odds ratio (OR) or Cross-product ratio: Measures strength of the association between exposure and outcome (Option C) . It is a key parameter in the analysis of case-control studies (Option B) . Used for categorical variables. Provides relative risk estimation. Interpretation: (Option D) . OR > 1 Positive association or possible risk factor OR = 1 No association OR < 1 Negative association, inverse association, or protective factor Note: Incidence rate refers to the number of new disease cases in a specific population over a defined period. (Option A) . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 81

questions.question: Below is a graphical representation of the odds ratio (OR) and risk ratio (RR) for various incidence rates. Which of the following is false?

options.A: As RR increases, OR increases at a higher rate for all incidence rates
options.C: The yellow line represents a much larger OR than the RR
options.D: The pink line represents a lower incidence rate.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) OR always underestimates the RR Explanation: The odds ratio always overestimates the risk ratio. The colourful lines represent incidence rates. The blue dotted line indicates OR = RR. The odds ratio provides an estimation of relative risk. As the RR increases, the OR increases at a higher rate for all incidence rates (Option A) . High incidence rate (yellow) = OR is much larger than RR (Option C) . Low incidence rate (pink) = OR is similar (but still larger than RR) (Option D) . The difference between the OR and RR increases as the OR gets higher. In case of a rare disease: OR = RR

questions.question: To investigate the association between high cholesterol levels and the development of hypertension, researchers collected data from 100 patients with hypertension and 210 patients without disease. 60 patients had high cholesterol levels in the hypertensive group, while 30 patients had high cholesterol levels in the non-hypertensive group. What are the odds of having high cholesterol levels in hypertensive patients?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 9.0 Explanation: Calculation of Odds Ratio (OR): Identify the data: Cases with high cholesterol: 60 Cases without high cholesterol: 40 (100 - 60) Controls with high cholesterol: 30 Controls without high cholesterol: 180 (210 - 30) Risk Factor/Exposure High cholesterol Low cholesterol Hypertension 60 (a) 40 (b) No hypertension 30 (c) 180 (d) Odds of exposure among cases: a/d = 60/40 = 1.5 Odds of exposure among controls: = c/d = 30/180 = 0.1667 Odds ratio (OR) = (odds of exposure among cases) / (odds of exposure among controls) OR = ad/bc = 1.5 / 0.1667 = 9 Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 81

questions.question: A research team conducts a study to investigate the association between smoking and bladder cancer. They select a group of patients with and without bladder cancer and compare their smoking history. Which of the following best describes the significance of the study in this scenario?

options.A: It allows for the determination of the incidence of bladder cancer among smokers and non-smokers.
options.B: It helps to establish a temporal relationship between smoking and bladder cancer.
options.C: It is a cost-effective and efficient way to study the association between smoking and bladder cancer.
options.D: It can be used to follow patients over time to observe the development of bladder cancer.

questions.explanation: and bladder cancer. Correct Answer: C) It is a cost-effective and efficient way to study the association between smoking and bladder cancer Explanation: Case-control studies are cost-effective and efficient for studying the association between exposure (smoking) and outcome (lung cancer), especially when the outcome is rare. Aspect Case-Control Study Cohort Study Definition Compares individuals with a disease (cases) to those without (controls) Follows a group (cohort) over time to see who develops the disease. Study Design Retrospective or prospective. Prospective (or retrospective in some designs). Data Collection Usually relies on existing records or interviews Collects data over time, often with direct measurements. Population Starts with disease status (cases vs. controls) Starts with exposure status (exposed vs. unexposed). Advantages - Quick and inexpensive. - Useful for rare diseases. - Can study multiple exposures. - Can establish temporal relationships. - Useful for studying multiple outcomes. - Less bias in exposure measurement Disadvantages - Prone to recall bias. - Cannot directly measure incidence. - Selection bias may occur. - Time-consuming and expensive. - Requires large sample sizes. - Loss to follow-up can affect results. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 78-85

questions.question: To investigate the relationship between hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and breast cancer, researchers conducted a study where they selected patients with breast cancer from an ongoing cohort study and compared HRT usage among cancer-free women from the same cohort. What type of study design does this scenario indicate?

options.A: Cohort study
options.C: Nested case-control study
options.D: Cross-sectional study

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nested case-control study Explanation: Researchers conducted a nested case-control study using a subset of cancer patients (cases) and cancer-free people (controls) from an ongoing cohort study. Nested case-control study: A type of case-control study that draws its cases and controls from a defined cohort. Data collection is prospective. Combines the efficiency of a case-control study (feasible for rare outcomes, cost-effective) with some of the advantages of a cohort study, such as the ability to establish temporality and reduce recall bias. In a cohort study (Option A ) , researchers follow a group of individuals (the cohort) to observe how exposures affect the incidence of outcomes. This study design was not used in the scenario since the cases and controls were selected from an existing cohort rather than being followed from the start. A case-control study (Option B) involves identifying individuals with the outcome of interest (cases) and comparing their past exposures to those without the outcome (controls). Unlike in a nested case-control study, these individuals are not selected from an existing cohort. A cross-sectional study (Option D) examines exposure and outcome status at a single time. This design does not follow participants over time and cannot establish causality or temporality. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7845919/

questions.question: The following are some steps taken to investigate an epidemic. Arrange the steps in the correct sequence. Verification of the diagnosis. Define the population at risk. Data analysis. Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic. Evaluation of ecological factors. Testing of hypothesis.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1, 4, 2, 3, 6, 5 Explanation: Steps in the investigation of an epidemic: Steps Salient points 1 Verification of diagnosis Most important step Examination of a sample of cases and verify the diagnosis To avoid a spurious diagnosis based on signs and symptoms. 2 Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic Compare data collected with the previous year's data. Epidemic: Occurrence > 2 S.D. The cases occur at over 80% of the expected frequency. 3 Defining the population at risk Obtain a map of the area affected. A house-to-house survey is done to find the entire population at risk. 4 Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics Medical survey. Epidemiological case sheet. 5 Data analysis Done in terms of Time, Place and person Try to identify the type of epidemic by drawing the epidemic curve. 6 Formulation of hypothesis It contains information about the agent, host, environment, modes of transmission, etc. Formulation of a hypothesis is the work of descriptive epidemiology. 7 Testing of hypothesis First step: Case-control study. Second step: Plan a cohort study to compare the attack rates in exposed vs non-exposed groups. 8 Evaluation of ecological factors Effect of humidity. Effect of sanitary conditions. Effect of water supply. 9 Further investigation of the population at risk Keep looking for any other population that is at risk. 10 Writing the report To provide a strategy at the end. Prevent future occurrences. The investigation of an epidemic can be stopped when no more cases occur for twice the incubation period of the disease from the occurrence of the last case. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 147, 148

questions.question: Which of the following is true about secular trends?

options.A: A roadside accident is a good example.
options.B: It is due to environmental factors.
options.C: This is due to the commonly occurring variation in herd immunity.
options.D: Consistent change in a particular direction over a period of time.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Consistent change in a particular direction over a period of time. Explanation: The secular trend implies changes in the occurrence of a disease, i.e., progressive increase or decrease in incidence over a long period of time, such as years or decades. Although it may have short-term fluctuations imposed on it, secular trends imply a constant tendency to change in a particular direction of a definite movement in one direction. Examples include diabetes mellitus, coronary heart disease, and lung cancer (an increase in the number of non-communicable diseases when compared to previous years). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 74

questions.question: Study designs are used for which of the following purposes?

options.A: Formulating a hypothesis
options.C: Confirming a hypothesis
options.D: All of the above

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: A hypothesis is an assumption yet to be verified by study designs. Purpose of study designs: Formulation of a hypothesis A hypothesis is formulated when no knowledge about a new disease exists. Descriptive epidemiology, which focuses on time, place, and person, helps in these cases. For instance, early in the COVID-19 outbreak, it was hypothesised as a type of pneumonia. Testing a hypothesis Testing addresses how and why a disease occurs and is a key aspect of Analytical epidemiology. Eg; comparing individuals with COVID-19 to those without it to understand the disease better. Confirmation of a hypothesis The disease is confirmed through Experimental or Interventional epidemiology. Eg; once COVID-19 was confirmed, vaccines and treatments were developed Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 78 Study Designs in Clinical Research- NIH

questions.question: What is the image given below used for?

options.A: Local distribution of a disease
options.C: National variation
options.D: Migration studies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Local distribution of a disease Explanation: The image shows a spot map, which is useful for determining the local distribution of a disease. Spot maps/Shaded maps: It is useful in outbreaks to determine the local distribution of a disease. Inner and outer city variations in disease frequency are well known. These variations are best studied using spot maps. They show areas of high and low frequency at a glance, the boundaries, and distribution. For example, if the map shows a clustering of cases, it may suggest a common source of infection or a common risk factor shared by all the cases. The classic example of the use of spot maps was by John Snow for the cholera epidemic in 1854. Migration studies: They compare disease and death rates between migrants and their new environment versus their place of origin. This helps identify whether changes in disease incidence are due to genetic factors or environmental exposures. There are two main types of comparisons: Between migrants and individuals who stayed in the country of origin to determine environmental effects. Between migrants and the local population in the new environment to distinguish the effects of new exposures.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes ‘person distribution’ in descriptive epidemiology?

options.A: The distribution of people across an area under study.
options.B: The population's disease analysis is based on the characteristics of the people who develop them.
options.C: Distribution of human resources to various tasks of the study.
options.D: Distribution of residents within different neighbourhoods or urban areas.

questions.explanation: who develop them. Correct Answer: B) The population's disease analysis is based on the characteristics of the people who develop them. Explanation: Person distribution in descriptive epidemiology involves analysing disease patterns based on demographic characteristics such as age, sex, race, occupation, and other factors of the individuals who develop the disease. The distribution of people across an area under study: Describes the geographical distribution of a population. Focuses on where people live in a given area, emphasizing place distribution rather than individual characteristics related to disease. Distribution of human resources to various tasks of the study: Addresses the logistical aspect of study conduct. Involves allocation of researchers and resources to different tasks, not related to person distribution in epidemiology. Distribution of residents within different neighbourhoods or urban areas: Concerns the spatial distribution of residents within a city or region. Focuses on place distribution, lacking emphasis on individual characteristics that define person distribution in epidemiology. Understanding these host factors aids in epidemiological studies, identifying high-risk groups, and informing preventive strategies. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 76

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes a propagated epidemic? epidemic curve.

options.A: It is typically caused by a single brief and simultaneous exposure to a common source.
options.B: It shows an epidemic curve with one peak that rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves.
options.C: Transmission occurs gradually through person-to-person transmission, rising and tailing off in the
options.D: A propagated epidemic can only occur if the disease has a short incubation period.

questions.explanation: and tailing off in the epidemic curve. Correct Answer: C) Transmission occurs gradually through person-to-person transmission, rising and tailing off in the epidemic curve. Explanation: Propagated epidemic: Most often of infectious origin. Person-to-person transmission. Gradual rise and tailing off. It can occur with diseases that have varying incubation periods. E.g. HIV/AIDS, which has a long incubation period but spreads through person-to-person contact, leading to a propagated epidemic. To stop transmission, the number of susceptibles should be reduced or the susceptibles should be protected from exposure. Herd immunity, contact opportunities, and secondary attack rates determine the speed of spread. Aggregating many susceptibles or a regular supply (birth, immigration etc.) of susceptibles favours the development of propagated epidemics. Examples: Hepatitis A, polio. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 73

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a common source epidemic with a single exposure?

options.A: The epidemic curve shows a rapid increase and decrease in cases.
options.B: Cases are spread across multiple incubation periods of the disease.
options.C: The epidemic often appears as an explosive outbreak with cases clustered quickly.
options.D: Most cases occur within a single incubation period of the disease.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cases are spread across multiple incubation periods of the disease. Explanation: Common source Epidemics: Properties Point source or single exposure epidemic Continuous or repeated exposure Intermittent exposure Exposure Timing Brief and simultaneous Prolonged, continuous, repeated, or intermittent Intermittent Incubation Period All cases develop within one incubation period (Option D) Cases develop over multiple incubation periods (Option B) Unrelated to the incubation period Epidemic Curve Single peak; rises and falls rapidly (Option A) Extended or irregular curve Multiple peaks Explosiveness Explosive with rapid clustering of cases (Option C) No explosive rise in cases - Secondary waves None May continue without clear secondary waves - Disease Agent Source Often due to a single infectious agent or contaminant Prolonged or repeated exposure to an infectious agent or contaminant - Examples Food poisoning. Industrial contamination (e.g., Bhopal gas tragedy, Minamata disease) Contaminated water source. Continuous exposure to pollutants. Prolonged outbreaks (Legionnaires disease) Contaminated food or tinned product which is sold over a period of time.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly distinguishes between hyperendemic and holoendemic diseases with appropriate examples? Africa regions

options.A: Hyperendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa Holoendemic- Common cold worldwide
options.B: Hyperendemic- Influenza during winter in temperate regions Holoendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan
options.C: Hyperendemic- Tuberculosis in urban areas Holoendemic- Seasonal influenza
options.D: Hyperendemic- Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa Holoendemic- Influenza during winter in temperate

questions.explanation: Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa Correct Answer: B) Hyperendemic - Influenza during winter in temperate regions; Holoendemic - Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa. Explanation: Hyperendemic : Constant presence of a disease at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate within a particular geographic area or population. It affects all age groups equally. Example: Influenza during winter in temperate regions, where the disease is prevalent during certain seasons but affects all age groups similarly. Holoendemic : A high level of infection begins early in life and affects most of the child population, reaching a state of equilibrium such that the adult population is less commonly affected. Example: Malaria in sub-Saharan Africa, where children are heavily infected, and adults show much less evidence of the disease due to early-life exposure and partial immunity.

questions.question: Match the following terms related to disease distribution with their appropriate examples: Term Example i) Endemic a) A sudden surge in influenza cases during the winter months. ii) Epidemic b) The persistent occurrence of malaria in certain regions of Africa. iii) Pandemic c) Isolated instances of tetanus infection with no discernible pattern. iv) Sporadic d) The global spread of COVID-19 affecting multiple continents.

options.A: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c
options.C: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b
options.D: i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-b

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A)i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c Explanation: Term Definition Examples Epidemic Occurrence of disease clearly in excess of normal expectancy (Mean + 2SD or >80% expected frequency). Occurrence of even a single case of a previously eliminated disease. Occurrence of a single case of an exotic disease. Seasonal influenza outbreaks during winter months. Endemic Constant presence of a disease within a specific population. Epidemiologically linked cases in terms of time, place, or person. Malaria in Africa, TB in India Pandemic Global spread of a disease. Defined as an epidemic in a large population. Requires crossing 2 continents and 2 WHO-specific regions. HIV/AIDS, COVID-19. Sporadic They occur randomly and unpredictably, without any discernible pattern in time, location, or individual. There's no epidemiological link between the cases. Tetanus Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page101, 102.

questions.question: A public health researcher is investigating the association between air pollution and asthma in children. The researcher collects data from a population over several years, documenting the levels of air pollution and the incidence of new asthma cases. Which of the following best describes the study design?

options.A: Interventional study
options.C: Descriptive Study
options.D: Analytical Study - Case Control

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Analytical Study - Cohort Explanation: The researcher compares the levels of air pollution and the incidence of new asthma cases through a cohort study, an analytical epidemiological study. A cohort study is a study design that follows a group of individuals (cohort) to observe how different exposures affect the incidence of specific outcomes. Interventional Study (Option A): An interventional study, also known as an experimental study, involves the researcher actively intervening to modify one or more factors and observing the effects of these changes. Descriptive Study (Option C): A descriptive study primarily describes the characteristics of a population or phenomenon being studied. It does not aim to test hypotheses or investigate causal relationships. Analytical Study - Case Control (Option D): A case-control study is retrospective, starting with individuals who already have the outcome (e.g., asthma) and comparing them to those without the outcome to determine past exposures. In the scenario described, the researcher collects data prospectively which aligns with a cohort study. Classification of study designs: OBSERVATIONAL STUDIES EXPERIMENTAL/INTERVENTIONAL STUDIES Descriptive Analytical Case reports Ecological studies Randomised controlled trials Case series Case-control studies Field trials Cohort studies Community trials Cross-sectional studies Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 70

questions.question: What is the first step in determining a descriptive study design?

options.A: Defining the disease under study
options.C: Describe the disease in terms of time, place, and person
options.D: Formulate a hypothesis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Defining the population of interest Explanation: Steps in determining a descriptive study design: Step 1 Defining the population of interest is the first step in descriptive study design, i.e. the socio-demographic profiling of the population. For a population to be a part of a descriptive study design, it has to be: Stable. No migration Community participation: A sample of the population should represent the entire population Step 2 Define the disease under study (Option A) Step 3 Describe the disease in terms of time, place, and person (Option C) Step 4 Measure the disease, i.e. health indicators such as mortality, morbidity and disability rates. Step 5 Compare with known indices. Step 6 Formulate a hypothesis (Option D) Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 71

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding descriptive epidemiology?

options.A: It is a study of the distribution of disease w.r.t. time, place, and person
options.C: It is the first phase of epidemiological investigation
options.D: Descriptive epidemiology does not involve a comparison group

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It tests a hypothesis. Explanation: Analytical study designs to test a hypothesis (Option B) , and involves a comparison group (Option D) . Descriptive studies are used to formulate a hypothesis when nothing is known about a new type of disease. Descriptive epidemiology: Study of disease/health-related events distribution and identification of disease-associated characteristics. Characteristics of descriptive study: It is the 1st phase of the epidemiological investigation (Option C) . It is used to formulate a hypothesis. It studies the distribution of disease w.r.t time, place, and person (Option A). It does not involve a comparison group. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 71

questions.question: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?

options.A: Cohort study
options.C: Case-control study
options.D: Ecological study

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cross-sectional study Explanation: A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease in a population at a specific time. It is also known as a snapshot of the total population. Here it is cross sectional study because it calculates prevalence of a disease and relies on primary data, i.e., researcher collects the data himself. To assess the incidence, a Cohort study (Option A) starts by determining whether risk factors are present. Case-control study (Option C) determines if an exposure is associated with an outcome. It starts with diseased and non-diseased. An Ecological study (Option D) compares exposure and disease frequency in a series of populations. The unit of study is population. Ecological study uses secondary data. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Pages 78, 79, 83 Cross-Sectional Study

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding experimental studies is false?

options.A: Interventional study can confirm/discard a hypothesis
options.B: Healthy individuals are a unit of study in randomised clinical trials
options.C: Cost and ethical concerns are seen in experimental studies
options.D: Experimental studies often include control groups to compare the effects of the intervention.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Healthy individuals are units of study in randomised clinical trials. Explanation: In randomized controlled trials (experimental study), the study unit is individuals with a particular condition or disease that the intervention aims to treat or prevent. Experimental study Unit of study RCT Diseased individuals Field trials (e.g. Vaccine trials) Healthy Individuals Advantages Disadvantages Provides evidence for the direct effect of an intervention and its outcome. Hence, a disease can be confirmed using Experimental or Interventional epidemiology (Option A) . For example, vaccines and drug manufacturing took place after the confirmation of the COVID-19 virus. Cost: Experimental studies, especially large-scale RCTs, can be expensive to conduct (Option C). Evaluate the efficacy of new drugs, vaccines, and therapies and compare between two interventional groups. Ethical concerns: Ethical considerations often pose limitations on experimental studies (Option C). Experimental studies often include control groups to compare the effects of the intervention (Option D): This is true because having a control group allows us to compare outcomes between those who receive the intervention and those who do not. This comparison helps to isolate the intervention's effect, thereby providing stronger evidence about its efficacy and safety. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page70, 90

questions.question: Match column A's types of studies with the appropriate option in column B. COLUMN A COLUMN B a) Cross-sectional i) Testing of hypothesis b) Ecological ii) Prevalence c) Descriptive study iii) First Phase in Epidemiology d) Analytical study iv) Population as the unit of study

options.A: a-ii, b-iv, c- iii, d-i
options.C: a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
options.D: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-ii, b-iv, c- iii, d-i Explanation: Cross-sectional study examines a set of populations at a time, helping to determine a disease’s presence within the population and calculating prevalence. Ecological Study is the only observational study with a population as the unit of study, while all other studies use individuals as the unit. Descriptive study is the first phase of epidemiology that helps formulate a hypothesis. An analytical study tests the hypothesis. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page70-75

questions.question: In community medicine research, which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Case series are used to establish causality between an exposure and an outcome.
options.B: Case reports are descriptive studies, while case series are analytical studies
options.C: Case series is formed by compiling reports of cases with diverse characteristics
options.D: Case series do not include a comparison group

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Case series do not include a comparison group Explanation: Case report Case Series Includes a single individual with unique or unusual findings Aggregation or collection of case reports that have a similar finding (Option C) They are both a type of descriptive study and do not require a comparison group (Option B) Case series provide detailed information about patients with a particular condition's clinical features, treatment, and outcomes. Establishing causality requires analytical study designs like cohort studies or randomized controlled trials (Option A) . Reference: Case Reports & Case Series

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of analytical study?

options.A: The subject of interest is the population
options.B: The subject of interest is an individual within the population
options.C: Helps in formulating a hypothesis
options.D: No comparison group is present

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Subject of interest is an individual within the population. Explanation: Differences between descriptive and analytical study: Descriptive Study Analytical study The subject of interest is population (Option A) The subject of interest is an individual within the population (Option B) , except in ecological study where the unit is population A comparison group is not present (Option D) A comparison group is present Helps in formulating a hypothesis (Option C) Helps is testing a hypothesis E.g.
